An intern accidentally leaked half the RSA private key bits on the company blog. Can you decrypt the secret message? Cipher: 2732435629331836843399046470242568344335710611418295376942253207845808345363110819483847153101409349165545445221990270908775521939734161955348358385500820

The flag format is flag{...}
n=5518313094490075393670875817458202593072436471854605997192071117997654243400250327942541798566080098270132495101806783217339758796050385683460438885916421, e=4876010688305731457041877914514425933678735936998675026676014804428962450482570062533676010066266776491885305614105938991585659357583672843814038658698467, partial_p=9606963384180060047

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{ryw8fjx2}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 2732435629331836843399046470242568344335710611418295376942253207845808345363110819483847153101409349165545445221990270908775521939734161955348358385500820
vulnerability: partial key exposure
hint: A partial exposure of a prime number's bits can significantly weaken RSA security. Look into lattice-based techniques like Coppersmith's attack.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=5518313094490075393670875817458202593072436471854605997192071117997654243400250327942541798566080098270132495101806783217339758796050385683460438885916421, e=4876010688305731457041877914514425933678735936998675026676014804428962450482570062533676010066266776491885305614105938991585659357583672843814038658698467, partial_p=9606963384180060047
extra_info: p=60303886530632954418147738663958458710640549179749969917476001731822554790347, q=91508415327209503786717547662568777956070948677724008634213731627329341714543, Ï†(n)=5518313094490075393670875817458202593072436471854605997192071117997654243400098515640683956107875232983805967865140071719482284817498695950101286989411532
subtype: partial_key_exposure
